abstract: A publicity firm builds expertise in online marketing after creating a blog written in the voice of the office dog.
snippet: A publicity firm builds expertise in online marketing after creating a blog written in the voice of the office dog.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, when I blogged about working alongside my new puppy, Sinatra, I asked readers to tell me about their experiences of working with dogs. (Please excuse my unintentional discrimination; I should have been more inclusive of the array of furry, and probably nonfurry, workplace companions out there.) I received many photos of pets engaged in adorable (or just lazy) antics around the office. But the most productive pet I heard about was Bella, the boxer, who is listed as director of goodwill at the public relations firm, Galvin Communications, in Portland, Ore.

headline.main: More Workplace Lessons From the Canine Set

abstract: The Loblaw Companies reported an increase in first-quarter profit and said it planned to accelerate price and cost cuts to compete with Wal-Mart Stores.

lead_paragraph: The Loblaw Companies, Canada’s largest supermarket chain, reported an increase in first-quarter profit and said it planned to accelerate price and cost cuts to compete with Wal-Mart Stores. Net income climbed 15 percent, to 62 million Canadian dollars ($61.2 million), or 23 cents a share, from 54 million Canadian dollars, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier, when it recorded costs for cutting jobs. Sales rose 2.8 percent, to 6.53 billion Canadian dollars. The executive chairman, Galen G. Weston, said price cuts would continue this year as Loblaw tries to blunt Wal-Mart’s expansion into fresh foods across Canada.

abstract: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, said first-quarter profit fell 12 percent, hurt by generic competition to the Ambien sleeping pill and by the decline of the dollar.

lead_paragraph: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, said first-quarter profit fell 12 percent, hurt by generic competition to the Ambien sleeping pill and by the decline of the dollar. Net income dropped to 1.86 billion euros ($2.9 billion), or 1.41 euros a share, from 2.12 billion euros, or 1.57 euros a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 3.3 percent, to 6.94 billion euros. Sales of Ambien, which lost patent protection a year ago, fell 65 percent, countering higher revenue from the Lantus diabetes medicine and the Lovenox anticlotting drug.

headline.main: France: Drug Maker Posts a Decline

abstract: A bevy of bloggers weigh in on the age-old career quandary — is choosing work you love a recipe for financial success?
snippet: A bevy of bloggers weigh in on the age-old career quandary — is choosing work you love a recipe for financial success?
lead_paragraph: If there is one question that plagues so many of us in our career choices, it is whether it is wise — or even possible — to build careers out of our passions. And there’s a corollary question that often goes along with it: Will financial success necessarily come to those who follow their passions? I’ve covered this before, but I just discovered an excellent post on Chris Guillebeau’s blog, The Art of Non-Conformity, in which several of my favorite bloggers chime in on this subject. (Thanks to Gretchen Rubin, of The Happiness Project, for bringing it to my attention.)

headline.main: Does Money Follow Passion? Top Bloggers Weigh In

Petroleum output dropped 1.7 percent, however, to the equivalent of 2.6 million barrels of crude a day. Chevron’s chief executive, David J. O’Reilly, plans to spend more than $400 million a week this year in the company’s costliest push ever to find new reserves, tap discoveries and expand refineries.

abstract: Singapore Airlines is launching a new all-business-class service between Newark and Singapore.
snippet: Singapore Airlines is launching a new all-business-class service between Newark and Singapore.
lead_paragraph: NEW SINGAPORE SERVICE Singapore Airlines is starting a new all-business-class service between Newark and Singapore on May 15, using Airbus A340-500 ultra-long-haul airliners configured with 100 flat-bed business-class seats. James Boyd, a Singapore Airlines spokesman, said demand for all-business-class service on the 18 ½-hour nonstop flight to Singapore has been “very strong.” Singapore Airlines also plans to begin all-business-class service between Los Angeles and Singapore in September, making it the first airline to offer this service across the Pacific, he said. The airline is converting cabins on five of its A340-500s  which it normally flies configured with 181 seats in two classes  for use in the new service.

abstract: After a family crisis, returning to work can happen in stages — the body may show up, but the mind may take a while to follow.
snippet: After a family crisis, returning to work can happen in stages — the body may show up, but the mind may take a while to follow.
lead_paragraph: It has been quiet at Shifting Careers this week because I took an unexpected trip to Florida for a death in my family. I was only gone three days. But because I left suddenly, I have returned to a personal and work life in chaos. Meetings and appointments missed need to be rescheduled. Deadlines that were comfortably far away are now looming. E-mail and phone messages have piled up. And since I left Florida long before processing the loss, I am trying to get back into work when my mind is still down there with my mourning relatives.

headline.main: Working — or Not — After a Death in the  Family

abstract: India has expanded bans on trading of food futures as the government intensifies efforts to cool inflation that is at the highest level in more than three years.
snippet: India has expanded bans on trading of food futures as the government intensifies efforts to cool inflation that is at the highest level in more than three years.
lead_paragraph: India has expanded bans on trading of food futures as the government intensifies efforts to cool inflation that is at the highest level in more than three years. Trading in soybean oil, potatoes and chick peas will be suspended on exchanges including the Multi Commodity Exchange of India, said Anupam Mishra, a director at the Forward Markets Commission, an industry regulator. Trading in rubber futures will also be suspended. “We have written to the exchanges asking them to ban trading in these four commodities with immediate effect,” Mr. Mishra said Wednesday night in a telephone interview. “This ban will remain for at least for four months.”

headline.main: India: Trading in Food Futures Suspended
headline.print_headline: India: Trading In Food Futures Suspended

abstract: On Wednesday, they finally took Bear Stearns out behind the woodshed and ended its lingering misery. On that day, the plaintiffs’ attorneys in the last remaining viable lawsuit in New York against JPMorgan Chase and Bear withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction to halt the JPMorgan acquisition. Instead, the lawyers stated that they will pursue monetary damages. There is one more suit pending in federal court but it does not look significant.

abstract: Anyone planning to attend railroad giant CSX‘s contentious annual shareholder meeting next month in New Orleans will probably need a good map, sunscreen and a fly swatter. abstract: For the third consecutive week, CBS’s Thursday night line-up earned more viewers than any of its network competitors during every time slot of the night. Beginning with the second to last installment of “Survivor: Micronesia,” CBS drew 12.7 million viewers to lead the 8 p.m. hour, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS then dominated the rest of the night with “CSI” at 9 p.m. (17.8 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 p.m. (14.6 million).
lead_paragraph: For the third consecutive week, CBS’s Thursday night line-up earned more viewers than any of its network competitors during every time slot of the night. CBS then dominated the rest of the night with “CSI” at 9 p.m. (17.8 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 p.m. (14.6 million).

headline.main: Ratings: If It’s Thursday, It Must Be CBS

abstract: Google faces a conundrum. If it does a deal with Yahoo, it faces antitrust scrutiny. If it backs out, it leaves Yahoo hanging in the wind. Either way, it could harm its nice-guy image.
snippet: Google faces a conundrum. If it does a deal with Yahoo, it faces antitrust scrutiny. If it backs out, it leaves Yahoo hanging in the wind. Either way, it could harm its nice-guy image.
lead_paragraph: Will Google and Yahoo come together on a search advertising partnership? The two companies have been discussing an agreement under which Google would deliver some ads alongside Yahoo’s search results. Since Google on average earns much more than Yahoo for every search, the deal, at least in theory, would bolster Yahoo’s revenue. The two companies conducted a two-week experiment to make sure that was indeed true and both companies have called the test a success.

headline.main: Google-Yahoo: Deal or No Deal?

abstract: Microsoft asked Europe’s second-highest court to overturn or reduce a record fine of 899 million euros ($1.4 billion) from the European Union.
snippet: Microsoft asked Europe’s second-highest court to overturn or reduce a record fine of 899 million euros ($1.4 billion) from the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft asked Europe’s second-highest court to overturn or reduce a record fine of 899 million euros ($1.4 billion) from the European Union. The appeal was filed at the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg, a Microsoft spokesman, Jesse Verstraete, said in an e-mailed statement. The European Commission, the E.U.’s antitrust authority, fined the company on Feb. 27 for failing to comply with a 2004 antitrust order. Under that decision, in which Microsoft was fined 497 million euros, the E.U. ordered the software maker to provide data to rivals to allow servers to connect to the Windows platform.

headline.main: Microsoft Appeals $1.4 Billion Fine by Europe
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Appeals $1.4. Billion Fine By Europe

abstract: Fremont General, once a major subprime lender, may go bankrupt and wipe out shareholders because it will not have enough time or cash to complete the sale of its retail banking business.
snippet: Fremont General, once a major subprime lender, may go bankrupt and wipe out shareholders because it will not have enough time or cash to complete the sale of its retail banking business.
lead_paragraph: Fremont General, once a major subprime lender, may go bankrupt and wipe out shareholders because it will not have enough time or cash to complete the sale of its retail banking business. Fremont, based in Brea, Calif., is behind on required filings and does not know when it will be able to provide data needed to finish the sale to CapitalSource, according to a company statement and filing. After agreeing to sell mortgage servicing rights to a Goldman Sachs unit yesterday, Fremont said it had contracted to divest “substantially all” the bank’s remaining assets. “There can be no assurance that there will be any monies” left for Fremont’s shareholders, the company said.

headline.main: Short of Cash, Fremont May Not Complete a Deal

abstract: Six tips for improving your listening skills.
snippet: Six tips for improving your listening skills.
lead_paragraph: According to Gretchen Neels, a workplace consultant, most people have no idea when they are not listening — or when they are giving the impression to others that they are not listening. I wasn’t surprised to hear that, having grown up in a family where conversation is more of a competitive sport than a polite interaction. In our home, talking over one another and interrupting were fairly standard, and as a result our communication probably suffered. Mastering listening, Ms. Neels says, allows you to get things right the first time, build better relationships and find the nuances behind what is being said.

headline.main: What?

The mining and basic industries minister, Rodolfo Sanz, will begin running the company immediately, Mr. Chávez said in comments broadcast by state television. abstract: India’s industrial production in March grew at the slowest pace since 2002, as borrowing costs hit a six-year high and discouraged consumer spending.
snippet: India’s industrial production in March grew at the slowest pace since 2002, as borrowing costs hit a six-year high and discouraged consumer spending.
lead_paragraph: India’s industrial production in March grew at the slowest pace since 2002, as borrowing costs hit a six-year high and discouraged consumer spending. Production at factories, utilities and mines rose 3 percent from a year earlier after gaining 8.6 percent in February, the statistics office said. “Industry is facing headwinds from tight monetary conditions, high raw material costs and weakening foreign demand,” said Sonal Varma, an economist in Mumbai with Lehman Brothers. Manufacturing, which accounts for about 80 percent of India’s industrial production, gained 2.9 percent in March, compared with a 16 percent increase a year ago. Electricity output rose 3.7 percent, mining grew 3.8 percent and consumer goods production fell 0.1 percent.

headline.main: India: Industrial Output Growth Slows

abstract: Société Générale, the French bank that lost billions from a rogue trader, disclosed today that it had restated quarterly income figures for last year to account for the unauthorized trades. The audited numbers, which the company admitted violated accounting standards, now turn out to have been wrong. (The violation of accounting standards, as I explained in this column, involved shifting losses taken in 2008 to 2007. The company got its auditors to agree that was fine, despite the rules.)

abstract: The end of a decade-long European ban on poultry imports from the United States moved a step closer after the European Commission promised to put forward a formal proposal to lift the embargo.

lead_paragraph: The end of a decade-long European ban on poultry imports from the United States moved a step closer after the European Commission promised to put forward a formal proposal to lift the embargo. Still, the concession, which was made during talks between the European Union and the United States, is likely to come with conditions and would require the approval of individual European Union governments. The ban was imposed in 1997 because of the common practice in the United States of cleaning chicken carcasses with a chlorine wash. Policy makers in the United States say there is no evidence that the process is harmful to human health.

headline.main: Ban on U.S. Chicken Imports Might End

lead_paragraph: South Africa, the world’s biggest precious metals producer, said mining output fell 17 percent in March because of power shortages. abstract: Microsoft‘s latest overture to Yahoo has raised a lot of questions about what exactly it wants from the new round of negotiations. What we do know for sure from the statement it issued Sunday is that Microsoft isn’t currently pursuing an acquisition of all of Yahoo. lead_paragraph: Microsoft‘s latest overture to Yahoo has raised a lot of questions about what exactly it wants from the new round of negotiations. What we do know for sure from the statement it issued Sunday is that Microsoft isn’t currently pursuing an acquisition of all of Yahoo. That leaves all kinds of other possibilities, including joint ventures, partnerships or a deal to acquire just a piece of Yahoo.

headline.main: What Does Microsoft Want?

lead_paragraph: Last week, I had lunch with the lawyer I worked with nearly 15 years ago in my first job. As we sat across a table the way we had countless times before, I realized that he was the reason I stayed so long in a career that wasn’t suited to me. I enjoyed working with him so much that I didn’t focus on the fact that I didn’t want to be a lawyer. But it’s a good thing I stayed because he taught me many things that made me successful in my career long after I left his firm and his field.

headline.main: Lessons From My First Boss

abstract: PSA Peugeot Citroën, the European carmaker, and a Japanese rival, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation have agreed to build sport utility vehicles and midsize cars in Russia.

lead_paragraph: PSA Peugeot Citroën, the European carmaker, and a Japanese rival, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation have agreed to build sport utility vehicles and midsize cars in Russia, Europe’s fastest-growing major auto market. Peugeot will invest as much as 350 million euros ($543 million) in a plant near Kaluga, 112 miles southwest of Moscow, Christian Streiff, the chief executive, said. The factory will initially make 160,000 vehicles a year, of which 50,000 will be S.U.V.’s, and eventually increase production to 300,000. The Peugeot-Mitsubishi plant will open in 2011, employing 3,000 people, Mr. Streiff said. Peugeot will hold a 70 percent stake, he said.

headline.main: Russia: Plans for a Car Plant

abstract: The government of Iceland’s bond rating was lowered to Aa1 from Aaa by Moody’s Investors Service on growing concern that the country’s banks may face a credit squeeze.
snippet: The government of Iceland’s bond rating was lowered to Aa1 from Aaa by Moody’s Investors Service on growing concern that the country’s banks may face a credit squeeze.
lead_paragraph: The government of Iceland’s bond rating was lowered to Aa1 from Aaa by Moody’s Investors Service on growing concern that the country’s banks may face a credit squeeze. The rating on the foreign currency country ceiling for bank deposits was also reduced one rank to Aa1 from the top level, Moody’s said. Iceland’s banks may encounter “liquidity constraints” because their assets are mostly denominated in foreign currency, according to Moody’s. The move comes four days after Iceland was offered an emergency loan by the central banks of Denmark, Sweden and Norway to support the krona and avert an economic collapse. The offer is evidence that Iceland still has access to funds and that liquidity risk should not be overstated, Moody’s said.

headline.main: Iceland: Bond Rating Cut by Moody’s
headline.print_headline: Iceland: Bond Rating Cut By Moody’s

abstract: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about efforts by the Swiss bank UBS to raise additional capital misstated several figures. The bank will issue 760 million new shares at 21 francs or $20.43 each, not $5.03. That price is 31 percent below the Wednesday closing price of 30.64 francs or $29.81, not $7.34. UBS’s shareholder equity fell to 16.4 billion francs or $15.96 billion, not $3.92 billion, at the end of March, from 51.3 billion francs or $49.9 billion, not $12.2 billion, a year earlier.

abstract: Pacific Sunwear of California fell the most in six years in Nasdaq trading on Friday after the clothing chain said annual earnings would be less than it previously forecast.

lead_paragraph: Pacific Sunwear of California fell the most in six years in Nasdaq trading on Friday after the clothing chain said annual earnings would be less than it previously forecast because of sluggish sales in states hit by the housing slump. Pacific Sunwear predicted profit of 59 to 64 cents a share, excluding some items, for the year through early 2009. In March, the retailer of surf-themed T-shirts, shorts and sweatshirts projected earnings of at least 73 cents. Analysts had expected 67 cents. About a quarter of the company’s 942 PacSun stores are in California, Florida and the Southwest, areas reeling from the housing decline.

headline.main: Forecast Sends Pacific Sunwear Stock Price Tumbling

abstract: A reader shares the financial details of her family’s move from corporate life to entrepreneurship.
snippet: A reader shares the financial details of her family’s move from corporate life to entrepreneurship.
lead_paragraph: Many of the questions I get from readers have to do with money — specifically how people fund a career shift. I try to get these financial details as often as possible, and I recently heard from a reader, Nina Murphy, whose story of how her husband, Bart Ferris, left the corporate world to start a gourmet foods company with a partner touched on just this issue. It turns out that Ms. Murphy was a big part of the story herself since she is bringing her own skills to her husband’s venture by working as the company’s publicist. (Career reinvention is always a little easier with a supportive spouse in the wings. But that’s a subject for another post.) I asked Ms. Murphy to tell their story here in the blog, with a focus on how they managed the financial side of things. And now, I’ll leave it to Ms. Murphy:

headline.main: Behind a Start-Up: One Family’s Choices

lead_paragraph: FARE INCREASES The six network airlines put in place another round of fare increases over the holiday, ranging up to $60 for a round-trip ticket, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive officer of Farecompare.com. It was the 11th fare increase of the year that all six major carriers had joined in. Despite the wide-ranging fare increases, airlines have been “very cautious” about increasing fares on routes where there is competition from Southwest, JetBlue and other low-cost carriers, Mr. Seaney said. Additionally, he said, airlines are now frequently “firing out short-duration sales” on fares for certain routes, mostly to fill seats on off-peak business travel days.

abstract: Criteria CaixaCorp agreed to buy 20 percent of Grupo Financiero Inbursa, a Mexico City bank, to tap into that country’s economic growth.
snippet: Criteria CaixaCorp agreed to buy 20 percent of Grupo Financiero Inbursa, a Mexico City bank, to tap into that country’s economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Criteria CaixaCorp, the investment company owned by Spain’s biggest savings bank, agreed to buy 20 percent of Grupo Financiero Inbursa, a Mexico City bank owned by the billionaire investor Carlos Slim, for 1.5 billion euros ($2.4 billion) to tap economic growth in Mexico. Criteria will pay 38.5 pesos ($3.71) a share for the holding, a premium of 8.6 percent above the Inbursa’s May 23 closing price, the Spanish company said Monday in a filing. Criteria, a unit of Barcelona-based La Caixa, which holds stakes in businesses worth about 24 billion euros, is buying the stock in Inbursa to diversify in a major Spanish-speaking country as the bank faces the increasing chance of a recession at home. The Mexican bank was set up in 1984 by Mr. Slim, the world’s second-richest man after Warren E. Buffett, according to Forbes magazine.

headline.main: Spanish Company Buys Stake in Mexico Bank
headline.print_headline: Spanish Company Buys Stake In Mexico Bank

abstract: Bell Canada is appealing a court decision that withdrew approval for a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company last week.
snippet: Bell Canada is appealing a court decision that withdrew approval for a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company last week.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of Canada said on Monday that it would accelerate its process to consider Bell Canada’s appeal of a court decision that withdrew approval for a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company last week. While the high court has yet to decide if it will hear Bell’s appeal, it issued a notice to both the company and its disgruntled bondholders indicating that June 17 is available for a hearing and setting a rapid timetable for filings. A Quebec appeals court sided with bondholders last week because Bell had not considered the impact of the buyout on their holdings. The buyout will add about 30 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in United States funds) in debt to the company, depressing the value of current bonds. Bell asked the court to rule by June 30, the closing date for the deal. The bondholders, in a separate court filing on Monday, rejected that idea and suggested that Bell and the buyout group, led by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, should simply make the closing date later rather than expect the court to rush its decision.

headline.main: High Court Sets Date on Bell Canada Appeal
headline.print_headline: High Court Sets Date On Bell Canada Appeal

abstract: China Mobile lost more than $26 billion in market value in Hong Kong trading on Monday after the government said it would merge smaller operators to increase competition.
snippet: China Mobile lost more than $26 billion in market value in Hong Kong trading on Monday after the government said it would merge smaller operators to increase competition.
lead_paragraph: China Mobile, which counts more than two-thirds of the nation’s mobile phone users as customers, lost more than $26 billion in market value in Hong Kong trading on Monday after the government said it would merge smaller operators to increase competition. The shares fell 8.2 percent to close at 114.90 Hong Kong dollars ($14.93), the biggest drop in more than six years. China’s two biggest fixed-line companies will also provide wireless services under the government plan announced Saturday, threatening China Mobile’s dominance of a market with 583.5 million customers. “The government wants to balance the telecom industry instead of having just one dominant player,” said Teresa Chow, who helps manage $1.1 billion at RBC Investment Management Asia in Hong Kong, including China Mobile shares.

headline.main: China Mobile’s Shares Fall 8% in Hong Kong Trading

abstract: Following the announcement that it may face more losses from mortgage securities, the bank fell the most in more than two months in Swiss trading on Monday.
snippet: Following the announcement that it may face more losses from mortgage securities, the bank fell the most in more than two months in Swiss trading on Monday.
lead_paragraph: UBS, the European bank hardest hit by the collapse of the subprime housing market in the United States, fell the most in more than two months in Swiss trading on Monday after it said it may face more losses from mortgage securities. UBS declined 5.8 percent to 28.20 francs in Zurich, and has dropped 43 percent this year, cutting its market value to 61.4 billion francs ($59.9 billion). UBS, in a prospectus for a 16 billion-franc rights offer to shareholders, said the bank’s losses on residential and commercial real-estate securities outside the United States “could increase in the future.” UBS is seeking to replenish capital after about $38 billion in write-downs related to the subprime crisis.

headline.main: UBS Foresees More Subprime-Related Losses

lead_paragraph: When Microsoft joined the One Laptop Per Child project earlier this month, I wrote an article noting the change in heart by both sides. The O.L.P.C. project, intended to bring cheap computers to children in poorer nations, had been committed to using the freely distributed Linux operating system, an open-source alternative to Microsoft’s Windows. And Microsoft had resisted joining anything that promoted open-source software.

snippet: The Sun-Times Media Group, the newspaper publisher once led by Conrad M. Black, won Canadian court approval of the settlement of a four-year dispute that will end control over the company by Hollinger Inc.
lead_paragraph: The Sun-Times Media Group, the newspaper publisher once led by Conrad M. Black, won Canadian court approval of the settlement of a four-year dispute that will end control over the company by Hollinger Inc. Hollinger, Mr. Black’s former Toronto-based holding company, will convert its supervoting shares in Sun-Times to common stock under an agreement approved by Ontario Superior Court Judge Colin L. Campbell. Mr. Black, convicted of fraud last year and sent to prison, helped build Sun-Times, formerly called Hollinger International, into the world’s third-largest publisher of English-language newspapers, before selling most of its properties in a $3 billion strip-down of assets from 1998 to 2001.

headline.main: Canada: Hollinger Control of Sun-Times Ends

abstract: The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista, below, is planning a 5.59 billion real ($3.37 billion) initial public offering of OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes.
snippet: The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista, below, is planning a 5.59 billion real ($3.37 billion) initial public offering of OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes.
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista, below, is planning a 5.59 billion real ($3.37 billion) initial public offering of OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes, betting the country’s recent oil finds will lure investors who snubbed other offerings this year. Mr. Batista founded Rio de Janeiro-based OGX less than a year ago. He paid $800 million in November to buy his first oil-exploration licenses off Brazil’s coast. Francisco Gros, vice president of the OGX board and former chief executive, said in an interview April 4 that OGX might have oil reserves of 4.8 billion barrels, according to a study by DeGolyer and MacNaughton, an oil-reserve appraisal firm based in Dallas.

lead_paragraph: The autofill feature of your spreadsheet program is a great way to save your hands from having to type common sets of data like the days of the week or months of the year. In Microsoft Excel, for example, type “January” into a cell and press the Enter key. Select the cell and drag the small square handle down 11 more cells to fill in the rest of the months. Illustrated instructions are at snipurl.com/2a4zt. You can do the same thing with Google Spreadsheets, as explained at snipurl.com/2a4zz. J. D. BIERSDORFER

abstract: It’s official: A majority of Bear Stearns shareholders on Thursday voted in favor of the securities firm’s sale to JPMorgan Chase. The approval — which was essentially a forgone conclusion, if only because JPMorgan already owned nearly half of Bear’s stock — clears the way for Bear to be subsumed into JPMorgan, ending its 85-year history as an independent entity. More than half of Bear’s employees are expected to lose their jobs in the sale, which was hastily arranged in March to avoid a complete collapse of the firm.
lead_paragraph: It’s official: A majority of Bear Stearns shareholders on Thursday voted in favor of the securities firm’s sale to JPMorgan Chase. The approval — which was essentially a forgone conclusion, if only because JPMorgan already owned nearly half of Bear’s stock — clears the way for Bear to be subsumed into JPMorgan, ending its 85-year history as an independent entity. More than half of Bear’s employees are expected to lose their jobs in the sale, which was hastily arranged in March to avoid a complete collapse of the firm.

headline.main: Bear Stearns: 1923 – 2008

abstract: There have been plenty of attacks in the last year or so on corporate boards’ use of compensation consultants to help determine how much to pay “C-suite” executives. But at least one line of criticism — focused on conflicts of interest — may be overstated, according to a new academic study highlighted by Compliance Week magazine. The study, whose authors include a professor at the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School, found that while the use of compensation consultants generally does pump up executive pay, the size of the increase doesn’t seem to be affected by other business ties between the consultant and the company.
lead_paragraph: There have been plenty of attacks in the last year or so on corporate boards’ use of compensation consultants to help determine how much to pay “C-suite” executives. But at least one line of criticism — focused on conflicts of interest — may be overstated, according to a new academic study highlighted by Compliance Week magazine. The study, whose authors include a professor at the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School, found that while the use of compensation consultants generally does pump up executive pay, the size of the increase doesn’t seem to be affected by other business ties between the consultant and the company.

headline.main: Pay Consultants and Conflicts: Not a Problem?

snippet: TransUnion, the credit reporting agency, won preliminary court approval to pay $75 million to settle lawsuits filed on behalf of as many as 150 million people.
lead_paragraph: TransUnion, the credit reporting agency, won preliminary court approval to pay $75 million to settle lawsuits filed on behalf of as many as 150 million people accusing it of improperly selling consumer credit information. The company would allow qualified consumers six months of unlimited free access to their credit reports and an as-yet undetermined cash award, under the terms of the accord approved by a Federal District Court judge, Robert Gettleman, in Chicago. The lawsuits accuse the company of selling marketing lists grouping consumers by their credit profiles, in violation of the federal law. TransUnion admits no wrongdoing in the settlement.

headline.main: Judge Approves Credit Bureau’s Settlement Plan
headline.print_headline: Judge Approves Credit Bureau’s Settlement Plan

abstract: An investor group led by NBC Universal and two private equity firms appeared to be leading the bidding for the Weather Channel.
snippet: An investor group led by NBC Universal and two private equity firms appeared to be leading the bidding for the Weather Channel.
lead_paragraph: An investor group led by NBC Universal and two private equity firms appeared to be leading the bidding for the Weather Channel, as final offers were due Friday night, people briefed on the matter said. NBC, the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital were offering about $3.5 billion including debt, these people said. About $1.8 billion of that was in cash, which would be split equally among the three investors. Other bidders for the channel include Time Warner, these people said. A winner may be announced as soon as next week. Landmark Communications, the privately held owner of the Weather Channel, is putting the weather-news heavyweight up for sale as part of a break-up of itself. Landmark originally sought to fetch $5 billion for the Weather Channel.

headline.main: Group Is Said to Bid $3.5 Billion for Weather Channel
headline.print_headline: Group Is Said To Bid $3.5. Billion For Weather Channel

abstract: Alcatel-Lucent shareholders, meeting in Paris, voted to make it easier for board members to dismiss and appoint the chief executive and chairman.
snippet: Alcatel-Lucent shareholders, meeting in Paris, voted to make it easier for board members to dismiss and appoint the chief executive and chairman.
lead_paragraph: Alcatel-Lucent shareholders, meeting in Paris, voted to make it easier for board members to dismiss and appoint the chief executive and chairman. The new rules allow board members to make such changes by a simple majority instead of the two-thirds majority previously required. “Good governance is clearly moving to majority voting, rather than super-majority voting,” said Patricia F. Russo, left, who has been chief executive since the company was created by a merger in 2006. Ms. Russo repeated a forecast that sales for telecommunications equipment will fall this year because of the dollar’s decline against the euro and possible spending delays at some clients.

headline.main: A Vote to Ease Executive Changes at Alcatel-Lucent
headline.print_headline: A Vote To Ease Executive Changes at Alcatel-Lucent

lead_paragraph: Alvin M. Marks, a prolific inventor who held patents on polarized film for sunglasses, a 3-D moviemaking process, a generator the size of a grapefruit that could produce enough electricity for a house, a windmill with no moving parts and a trillion-dollar “space train,” died Sunday in Gardner, Mass. He was 97 and lived in Athol, Mass.

Shattuck II, the last president of the company that owned Schrafft’s restaurants, a New York City-based chain that for decades offered home-style food in genteel surroundings to secretaries, errand boys, court clerks and others watchful of their wallets, died Saturday near his home in Bennington, Vt.
